content:
Yes, you can move the `groupby()` statement right after the `read_csv()` function. Here's an example:
```
import pandas as pd

#Read in the csv file
df = pd.read_csv('your_file.csv')

#Create a new dataframe containing each unique combination of the "CPT" column and the "BlueHost" column
df_grouped = df.groupby(['CPT','BlueHost']).size().reset_index(name='counts')

#Filter the dataframe to rows where the values in column "CPT" and "BlueHost" are equal to the specified values
df_filtered = df_grouped[(df_grouped['CPT'] == 'your_cpt_value') & (df_grouped['BlueHost'] == 'your_BlueHost_value')]

#Output the filtered dataframe to a new excel file with a specified tab name
df_filtered.to_excel('filtered_data.xlsx', sheet_name='your_tab_name', index=False)
```
You will have to replace "your\_file.csv" with the name of your csv file, "your\_cpt\_value" and "your\_BlueHost\_value" with the values you want to filter the dataframe on, and 'your\_tab\_name' with the tab name you want the sheet to have in the excel file. You will be filtering the new dataframe `df_grouped` which will have three columns, "CPT","BlueHost" and "counts" where "counts" column tells you the number of rows for each unique combination of the "CPT" and "BlueHost" columns from the read in dataframe.
